Just one pity. The fact that Cyberpunk 2077 is still a game full of all sorts of bugs. Outlast 2 is a successful sequel, but also conservative in terms of the gameplay formula. However, it will definitely not be a problem for fans of the first part and those who appreciate the traditional style of FPP horror movies.The assumptions are similar to the original, so the fans will immediately feel at home, although of course different and bigger. The environment changes, but the basis is still exploring, sneaking, hiding and tearing through locations, looking for a way out or finding an item, and avoiding enemies.The faithful camera returns. It is thanks to her - and the night vision mode - that we can see in the dark, where we spend a lot of time. However, it is worth manipulating the display mode to save the batteries, which we have to replace from time to time. The batteries are also consumed by the additional function of the sensitive distance microphone, thanks to which we can better determine the position of the opponent behind a building.

MechanicsIn Valheim, we observe the action from the third person perspective (TPP). We start the game in a relatively calm center of the procedurally generated land. Although we may feel moderately safe there, the area is not very rich in natural resources. On the other hand, we need resources to create a better and better arsenal and stronger armor, to build various structures, such as fortresses or outposts, as well as to produce food for our character.For this reason, with time we begin to venture further and further from the center; While we traverse dense forests, gloomy swamps or even snow-capped mountain peaks on foot, after reaching the seashore, we have nothing else to do but build a boat and go in search of unknown lands. Increasingly bolder exploration is associated with the need to face ever greater threats. The clashes with aggressive animals and mythical beasts are dynamic, and during them we have to show dexterity and reflexes to block enemy blows in time or dodge and launch counterattacks. We eliminate opponents by using melee weapons (such as swords and axes) and ranged weapons (such as various bows).Valheim: Hearth and HomeHearth and Home is the first major update released for Valheim. It implements many changes related to the mechanics of eating. Correlation between stamina and hit points has been removed. Introduced for three categories of meals that give different bonuses to the indicators mentioned above. Plants to induce vomiting were also added, thus emptying the stomach. There were also recipes for new dishes.After the update, there is also the possibility of having your own mount - you can put saddles on tamed Loxes, thanks to which you can ride them.Hearth and Home adds new furniture, resources and weapons to the game. The patch also changes the balance of weapons found in the game.StoryThe action of Valheim takes place in the title, tenth world, invented from scratch for the purposes of this production (it was not present in the Scandinavian cosmogony). Warriors come to Valheim, who want to deserve eternal glory and a place in Valhalla, have to traverse this land and face the beasts that inhabit it. Those who survive will eventually be adopted by the gods.

Doom is one of the best FPP shooters for years, being a breath of fresh air, providing players with pure joy from shooting - like in the old days. It is a game faithful to the original assumptions, but not different from the latest productions, on the contrary: the rest should learn from Doom. I had a great time playing this title - I recommend increasing the difficulty level, then the game is a challenge and provides even more satisfaction.

Ready or Not, the spiritual heir to the SWAT series. This is a tactical FPS in which we lead the members of the special division, created by the debuting studio Void Interactive. The game is currently available in an early versionVoid Interactive has created a realistic, tactical action game in which we can feel like members of a special unit, sent on subsequent missions in order to stop dangerous criminals. The authors took care of a lot of details. They introduced, among others a physical system that takes into account the penetration, expansion and momentum of bullets, ricochets, and the physics of Kevlar and armor.

The first few hours with Plague Inc. is wonderful. I couldn't tear myself away from the game, from trying different combinations of symptoms which sometimes resulted in great "combo" such as "zombie syndrome" - resulting from a combination of anemia and insomnia, or "projectile vomiting" from coughing and vomiting (helps spread the plague! ). It's a pity that playing some microbes is clearly less satisfying. My favorites are certainly bacteria, viruses and nano-viruses, although playing a parasite or a fungus is sometimes a chore and boredom.

God of War - is it worth it? Necessarily!  Absolutely!  Musowo!  I may have complained a bit, but it's good old Kratos.  Slightly changed, sometimes too dry and seemingly devoid of feelings, but still with the old sparkle in his eye and divine power in his paw.  It was incredibly good to meet him again after many years, even if instead of a typical slaughterhouse and flooding the screen with hectoliters of blood, he tries to tell us his story a bit differently. Because the new God of War focuses primarily on the story that he tells in various ways before our eyes, and this allows us to participate in it, and this allows us to delve into Atreus's note about the monsters he met, about forgotten gods, giants and their shared history. In this respect, the new adventures of Kratos are like a good adventure book that we read to the pillow.  Sometimes it scares, sometimes it makes you laugh, and sometimes it grabs your heart.  After all, we want this journey to last as long as possible, because it provides so many different emotions.  And if only that's why I'm going to bet that God of War will be able to defend itself even on PCs, up to 4 years after the console premiere.  This is a great game that it would be a sin not to play.

Reminds me a lot of Dungeon keeper series since it has the similar feature of "digging out" your own ant colony. It also reminds me of the Warcraft 3 map "Ant colony" which offers similar gameplay.  The game is entertaining and does have enough levels to justify the price in my opinion. Overall it's a fun game and despite its shortcomings I would still recommend it.

To begin my review, I want to comment on most of the negative reviews. No game today comes out without bugs. This is because PCs and software is different, and the developers do not have reasources to test it on all machines. This will however be fixed. I'm not working for Square Enix or Avalanche Studios, but I'm asking you to please reconsider your negative review of the game, because it annoys me that a game like this has a "mixed" score on Steam. This game really deserves more, and when the bugs are fixed and you're able to play, you will realise why. Here is my review of the game. Enjoy!Just Cause 3, not much different from Just Cause 2, just a whole lot better. You can still blow up everything you see, and do whatever you like. The flying mechanism is much alike, but you can now use a wingsuit, which to me makes the game a lot better than JC2. Instead of making this review look like a conglomerate, I will comment different aspects below:Graphics:I could write several pages about the graphics, but to make it short, I'll just say that I love the graphics, and they are improved alot more since JC2. The nature is more detailed, and the shaders look more beautiful.The explosions improved aswell, and even though explosions looked amazing from before, they managed to make them even better. Panau looked more like a plastic world to be honest. Just Cause 2 had crazy graphics at it's time, and Just Cause 3 managed to score well on graphics this time aswell. Great Job developers! Medici is beautiful!Physics:Let me just say it has not changed much, which is good. This game should not be realistic when it comes to physics. Things explode everywhere, and that's how I want my Just Cause, just cause. An important improvement is the lovely new grapple. You can now shoot several of them, and "tigthen" them to move objects closer to eachother. I have used this a lot with helicopters, and crashed them into the ground in a hilarious way.Game mechanics:As mentioned above, the new grapple is amazing. Another awesome feature in Just Cause 3 is the wingsuit, which I carefully commented above. Oh, how I love the wingsuit. Thanks to the winguit I'm able to fly from A to Z without having to use any vehicle or fast travel. The Fast Travel is great aswell, but it seems like a rarely used feature. I prefer the wing suit, definitely. The fact that you can shoot out several grappling hook wires is also amazing. Audio:The audio is similar to the one in Just Cause 2, but they made a few changes. One thing that really amazes me is the feeling after capturing a town. After the fireworks, I can hear a calm music in the background, making it seem like the city is a whole new place after probably years of propaganda speakers and killing soldiers. Some soundtracks are from Just Cause 2, but some are brand new aswell, and they are all awesome. Great Job!Story:After being dissapointed of the short Just Cause 2 story, I was not expecting any better story in Just Cause 3. Right now, I have played for 28 hours, and I have still not finished the story. You have a lot to do, which include random side quests and missions, aswell as tasks to do before unlocking missions. They have really put a lot of new activities to the game, like new challenges and races, and a brand new way of aquiring vehicles and weapons. You no longer have to wait for that annoying guy in the chopper (yay I guess).That was the most important good things to include, but I should also comment on the few things that I did not like. These are the major problems:* The AI is bad, and cars keep driving off bridges that I just exploded. Not much better than GTA though :)* Bases are too easy to capture. I want a more challenging way of doing it.* Had problems where sometimes in missions, music was not playing during intense scenes. Just a quick restart to fix it though.* Game crashed once, but I have not seen it again.* I have to get used to a whole new key setup. I guess it is better for the game, and I could change it back, but you learn it quickly.*The volcano island and the hidden island in the bottom left was empty. I was left with a huge dissapointment after just finding ruins and a racecar. The hidden/isolated island in JC2 had much more awesome features, where you could not fly in. Could be improved.* I love military bases, but the map could have a bit more of cities, as the biggest island consists mostly of no cities and civilian people. Not even villlages or farms.* No big airports other than military airportsOtherwise, the game is amazing. I love it, and I hope you do aswell! :) Vive la revolution!

After playing through SOMA, these are my thoughs:I bought the game, expecting a horrific and scary horror game. I hoped it to be as good as Amnesia: The dark decent. Unfortunately, Amnesia is not the best horror game I have played anymore. SOMA has beautiful graphics, scary moments, puzzles, and what I liked the most, A fantastic story. I felt like I was in the game when playing as Simon (which made it seem even more real because that's my name real name). Frictional Games managed to create a scary environment, just like in Amnesia. I noticed that many of the scenes were similar to Amnesia, and just as scary. I have heard many people say Amnesia is scarier, but in my opinion, this game is just as scary, except possibly the environment. Being in a futuristic underwater base might not sound as scary as being in a dark old castle, but Frictional Game managed to do this well.PROS:-The Story is beautiful.-The graphics look amazing.-Basically everything I said above.-Stable game with very little lag.-Fun and exciting puzzles. I was not bored for a minute.-Effects and realism, even though it's futuristic.CONS:-Had issues with fullscreen and VSync. Game ran at 30FPS. Managed to fix with Borderless window and VSync off. (Had no screen tearing).-When entering a base, the game stops running for a few seconds, probably just to load the base. The game crashed twice because of this. Not a huge issue because of autosave.That's my summary of the game. The only cons are optimalization issues, but they werent much of a problem. The game itself is quite stable, and a medium good computer should be able to run it well. I'm very satisfied with my purchase. If you're thinking of buying a horror game, this is definitely the one for you. Thanks for your attention, and have a nice day!

I had been waiting for this game to come out for months, and it's finally here. But would it live up to what I hoped?In a word, yes.It's not perfect by any means. The background music is a bit too quiet at times, especially further from the radio, and I don't want to carry it around with me all over the level. This is only a minor thing. Also, held items occasionally glitch (visually) through walls/doors that you approach while holding it. It hasn't, in my experience, actually affected gameplay or caused any problems.One other minor thing I've noticed is that sometimes when you throw an object, it can activate a switch that's well above it and which the object doesn't actually come into contact with. Not a huge deal, but something that will hopefully get patched later on.Is the game fun? Definitely. Sometimes you have to get damn creative to complete the levels. Do I regret taking the time to play it? Pfft, no. Definitely worth my time. Would I spend $5 on it? That's a tougher question. If you can get it for $2-3, go for it. I'd *probably* pick it up for $4, but $5 might be a bit of a stretch.The graphics are not bad at all. I'm playing in 4K and everything seems pretty smooth. Of course, round objects aren't smoothly round. That's not something I'm going to make a big fuss about though. It's meant to be more comical and not ultra-realistic anyway.Gameplay seems pretty solid. It opens with tutorials all over walls to teach you how to move around and interact with objects, including climbing ladders and crawling through small passageways. I really wish I could reassign the keys, but at least the assignments are relatively standard and convenient. Overall, it seems pretty good.The verdict: It's a bit of a shorter game, but definitely worth picking up for a few bucks. If you enjoy first-person puzzle games that aren't terribly complicated, you should have some fun. 8/10NOTE: The game isn't making fun of suicide or depression. It's based on the myth that you can never die in your dreams. Have you ever had a dream where you were about to die and you snapped awake? Basically, your character is stuck in a dream and can't wake up...so you have to make him "die" in his dream so he will be forced awake.

Woodle Tree is back in Woodle Tree 2: Worlds. This time, Woodle Tree's home has been invaded by an evil force and you have to fight them and beat them into submission in any brutal fashion (using your handy leaf) and send them back where they came from!This game is a cute 3D platformer/adventure game, with a number of collectible items and berries. I enjoy the open world, though the long loading times annoy me a bit. Thankfully, they don't come up very often. I'm running a very high-end PC, so I'm a little surprised at the load times, but it's not a big deal.I am very thankful for the tutorial path ahead of your home, not too far from your starting point. It gives visual depictions showing you what certain things do and how to perform actions and special moves. Unfortunately, since they are images, if you reassign your keys or mouse buttons, the ones in the image will not be the one triggering the action. This can't be avoided.It's a lot of fun to run around, whack bad guys (or even guys just chillin' minding their own business), and collect berries to get weapon upgrades, defense upgrades, and other perks. Woodle Tree 2 has a pretty decent drawing distance, but I wish it could draw as much as your computer can handle. I'd be able to render and see the entire Woodle universe. :)There are a couple of bugs. A minor one is that occasionally certain NPCs can walk through solid surfaces (like walking into the side of a raised patch of dirt) and occasionally you can walk through what looks like a wall. This could be intentional, but I'm not sure. The other bug (and this one is more serious) is that if you respawn after dying, and you attack an enemy that you already killed and respawned when you did, your attacks go right through it and don't harm it. I'm sure this is easily fixed and will be fixed before long.Good things to look forward to are unlimited lives (you respawn at the last checkpoint you triggered, clearly marked as a stump on the ground with a swirl inside it), unlimited ammo, more than a dozen upgrades and unlocks, a number of different enemies, a HUGE open world to explore, and collectibles that unlock furnishings and decorations for your house. I have no idea if the decorations are purely cosmetic or if they serve a purpose/function, but they don't seem to do anything. It's neat seeing them in your house, though.PROS:-------+ Unlimited lives (uses a checkpoint system)+ Massive amount of places and space to explore+ Several upgrades and unlockable perks+ Many collectibles+ Interesting and helpful tutorial area near your starting point+ Cute and very nice graphics without requiring a workhorse PC+ The areas I've explored so far are distinct from one another and easy to distinguish+ Excellent price for the amount of fun you can have with itCONS:-------- Still a couple of bugs to work out, but no big deal considering it's Early Access- Hitboxes seem slightly off (but mostly in your favor)- Can be a bit tricky to control your Woodle Tree and the camera until you get used to itOverall:If you like cute platformers like Super Mario 64 but want a lighter, simpler version, this can be the ticket. What are you going to do with $4 instead of buying this game? You can buy half of a beer at a sporting event, one combo meal at McDonald's (or not even a full one), or a small coffee at Starbuck's. This game will give you hours and hours of fun and it's about the price of 2 gallons of gasoline in the USA.This game will take you farther than 2 gallons of gasoline.

Woodle Tree Adventures is a fun little platformer with cute graphics and easy-to-learn gameplay mechanics. It is very simple to pick up and learn, and even a child can do it. You can even upgrade your weapon by "farming" the pickups, so you can farm the easiest ones to get to if you are having trouble and want to get an upgrade.It's a big plus that you are given unlimited "lives" and even if you die or fall off, you don't lose any progress in the level (except going back a bit geographically). All enemies vanquished stay gone, you keep any pickups and fairy tears you got on that level, and you are not penalized other than a bit of forward progress. That's a great thing that ensures the game can challenge you without becoming frustrating or problematic.So far, I've only played (and beaten) the first level, and it's been very fun. I'd compare it to a simpler Super Mario 64 with smoother graphics. The camera can be a bit awkward and you cannot rotate it (the game handles that automatically) but you can zoom in and out as you desire. If you like 3D platformers with simple controls and easy-to-understand mechanics, you'll probably like this game.It even comes with Steam trading cards, so if you pick it up cheap on sale you can recoup part or most of your investment and basically play it for free.Overall, this is a very fun game and even at full price is a very fair deal.10/10 would pimpslap a walking block with a yellow leaf again.

I will probably play it a lot more once the developers polish it more and add in some of those features I listed or put more in the game to do. Go ahead and get it while it's cheap. Its an unpopular opinion, but I do enjoy how menacing the Mechs are in the game, and how they are something to be avoided rather than being able to take them down with a bolt action rifle. That being said, I do hope they employ some kind of EMP devices in the future or some kind of counter to the mechs. As far as difficulty the most your going to have to worry about is very early game inventory management. There isnt much in the way right now as of base buildind, but you can chop a few trees down and make inventory boxes near towns and houses for loot farming. I enjoy the fact that loot in this game makes sense, for example, military bases have the highest yield for medical and firearms, houses for clothes and food with very rare chances for weapons. A lot of effort went into the game to get it where it is and from the developers YouTube channels they seem pretty adament about keeping this game alive and running. I am satisfied with my purchase.
